DIV1.P: DUBLIN: Printed by P. BYBND, 108, Grafton-Street. 179.

LIST.HEAD: WOMEN.
LIST.ITEM: Miss Sophia Strangeway, (Ward to Sir Andrew,) Mrs. Wells.
Honoria, (Niece to Colonel Hubbub,) Miss Esten.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE—An Apartment at Sir Andrew's—two Doors open. Bell rings—Enter James from Door and another Servant. Table and two Chairs.

SP.SPEAKER: James.
SP.P: RUN—fly—scamper—don't you hear the com∣pany are breaking up. Call Lord Jargon's carriage.

DIV3.STAGE: Lady ACID appears at door, curtesying as if taking leave of somebody.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Good night, my Lord—Delightful man! —I am determined he shall be in possession of Honoria, if it's only in return for his attachment to me. James call up the carriages, and see the company disposed of. I'm so fatigued!—heigh-ho!—seven o'clock again!—I hav'nt been to bed any sooner this fortnight.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Andrew, without.
SP.P: —Where are all the servants?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Here's my fretful husband just got up!—he's so old fashion'd, and so sour; he's never pleased, but when others are vexed; and never unhappy, but when his friends are happy.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir ANDREW in night-gown and cap.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —So my life! just got up I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —So my soul, just going to bed I suppose. What! at the old work—Rout, ball, or concert, heh! making fools happy with my money.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Psha! you've no idea of life.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —No; but I have of death. It would kill me in a fortnight; besides every body laughs at you. Not one of your acquaintance, who by the bye have loved and hated each other all round, but on leaving the room exclaims, "Well, it's very fine, mighty grand; but will it last; won't there be a crush by and bye."

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P:
—Ridiculous, Sir Andrew. An't I visitted by
every body? Don't all the beau monde attend Lady Acid's parties?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —The beau monde! Why they'll visit any body that is fool enough to invite them; let who will give an expensive entertainment, they'll flock to it, like rooks about a ruin—but this won't do; it's seven o'clock, and I must be eating. Here—you, Sir, bring my break∣fast,

SP.SPEAKER: James
SP.P: —Breakfast—what, here, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Yes, here, sir. I'm sure the beau monde, as your Ladyship calls them, will have no objection to something substantial. Poor Devils! at these sort of parties, they get nothing to feed on but scandal and Faro.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Provoking, Sir Andrew, you're always teaz∣ing and vexing me, and I insist on knowing what part of my conduct—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Hold—don't suppose I suspect your charac∣ter; no, 'midst all your gaieties, I still believe you to be so constant and honourable, that there's no indulg∣ing one's self in finding fault with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —If you don't think so, your cousin Colonel Hubbub does, or he never would have trusted me with the care of his niece Honoria. But I leave you to your ill-nature.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Aye; go to bed. You to your pillow, I to my coffee.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Mind me, Sir. If you see Honoria, give her the advice I desired you. Tell her the Colonel has written for his Ward Mr. Nominal, to challenge that wretch Clairville, and that I shall do all in my power to give her to Lord Jargon; and so good night, most good humour'd husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —And so good morning, most sweet-temper'd wife.

DIV3.P:
I've made her unhappy however—'gad; I don't know how it is, I like to see every body's face as long as my own— [breakfast brought in]—here it comes, and here's the paper [sitting down and taking up newspaper.] Now for it! now for bad news! Theatre Royal—new
comedy—Psha, making people grin, and distort their faces. Give me a deep, horrible, agreeable tragedy. Bankrupts—aye, here they are; one, two, three—thir∣teen. Come, very well; that's very well. Promoti∣ons—there they are with their curst joy again. Stocks fallen one and a half—some lame ducks, however.— Marriages, ten—well, long life to you, for you'll be as miserable—

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —Dear Sir, ten thousand pardons, I thought to have found your Ward Miss Strangeway, here.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Sit down, Honoria, sit down. I want to talk to you. Come, take some breakfast.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —Breakfast! I hav'nt been to rest yet. You for∣get the joys of high life, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Joys! she's happy too!—um—silly, ignorant girl, to take pleasure in such unmeaning scenes,

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —Pleasure! they give me pain, Sir—misery.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Do they! take some breakfast

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: What have I been doing to-night, Sir! talking to men I detest, and listening to women I despise; mix∣ing with people who have neither feeling, amity, nor sense. This I have done for years, and this I must still persevere in; for my education has taught me to smile when I was miserable, and to be fashionable at the ex∣pence of my peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Sweet creature; how prettily she prattles, Go on.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —Yes, Sir; with a mind naturally attached to domestic happiness, I am compelled to deride all peace∣ful scenes, because my uncle the Colonel, who has cruelly delivered me to the care of your wife, sir—but I interrupt you, I see I do—I'll keep my sorrows to myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Don't—don't keep them to yourself. I like to hear you talk about sorrow and misery; and if you know of any more elsewhere, you'll not offend me by imparting it. But now I think on't, tell me that un∣lucky story of the fellow ascending your window by a rope-ladder.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P:
—Fellow! Sir Andrew—when you are more
respectful, I'll talk to you—till when—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A—[Stopping her]
SP.P: Stay be not offended: I'll sym∣pathize with you, Honoria; I'll give you sigh for sigh, and tear for tear. Come, make me your confidant, and you shan't repent it; nay, you must, you shall. I do love to hear a tale of woe.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon—[Sighing]
SP.P: Oh sir! How have I been slandered and defamed. I never knew Mr. Clairville, but as a friend, as a protector. That we had secret meetings I cannot deny: but I was never alone; your Ward Sophia was always present, and she will witness to the world, that he was too honourable to make base proposals, and I too unfashionable to accept them.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Go on; I like to hear you, Honoria; if I re∣member, your acquaintance began at the Colonel's villa in the Isle of Wight, when you were sailing and fell from the vessel.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —Yes, Sir; and while his brother Lord Jargon and other foplings of the party, who before had offered up their lives to serve me, while they stood idly on the deck, and saw me just expiring. Clairville, then a stran∣ger, leap'd from another vessel, and plunging 'midst the waves, caught me in his arms, and brough me safe to land. Then came the conflict. The Colonel's boat, by adverse winds was blown from shore, and I and my Deliverer remained part of that day alone. I saw, com∣par'd, and lov'd. His heart beat in unison with mine; and now, sir, do you pity or condemn me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —I pity you, pity you sincerely, and curse the Colonel for placing you under the care of my wife, be∣cause I know she designs you for Lord Jargon. But Nominal, whom your uncle intends for your husband, who is hourly expected from France.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —Talk not of that, sir; for I dread the con∣sequences of his arrival. The night Clairville was dis∣covered in my apartment, the Colonel told him, he would send for his Ward Nominal, to avenge the in∣jured honour of his family. Ah, sir! if a duel should ensue—yet if Clairville receives my letter, that and other ills may be prevented [aside] but somebody is coming, sir; allow me to retire.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Do, and depend on my proection, Honoria; I am always a friend to the unhappy. Good morning.

DIV3.P: So there goes another long face.—Here's my Ward the celebrated Miss Alltrade; she is an authoress, an actress, a musician, a painter, and in short, every thing. I know she's in love with me, and I'll have the satisfaction of teazing her soul out.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Miss STRANGEWAY, with a Paper in her hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Sophia
SP.P: —Positively I will be revenged. The Colonel does nothing but make love to me—heigh-ho!—I'm so fatigued, Gaurdy—and it's vain going to bed, for I've so many places to call at

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —What! all over the town, as usual.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —Yes; first I'm going to Lady Bustle's, to finish my picture of her little French lap-dog: then to call at the bookseller's, and correct the press; then to leave this farewel ode to my dear Jugglamintha, at the newspaper office,

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Iron agonies of copper woe—that's a fine line, and charmingly distressing.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —Yes—then I'm going to rehearse a new Tra∣gedy at the private Theatre, and if you'll believe me, my dying scene is yet unsettled.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —That's a great pity, Sophia; for I think the dying scene the best part of the play.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —Yes; but one insists on my dying on one side of the stage; another on the other—now what am I to do?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Why what many great politicians have done before you! die between both sides. But, my angel, when am I to be honour'd with an assignation—a-tete-a-tete—heh!

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —Fie, Guardy; you know I told you I lov'd you better than the old Colonel, and—that I'd make fools of you both, before I'd done with you,

SP.SPEAKER: O'Whack—without,
SP.P: Arrah! stand by now!—I am the valet de chambre de Mr. Nominal.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P:
—As I live, Nominal is arrived. This is his Irish servant, who to his brogue has joined a smattering
of French—do stay, and hear him.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —What! mix Irish with French.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —So it seems—but here he comes.

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —Blood and ounds! don't you know me by my Politesse!—Jontleman and Lady, your most obedient. By the red nose of St. Patrick, I am toute nouveau; and d'ye see, I would be after speaking to my master's Guar∣dian Colonel Hubbub.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —How is your master? Is he as singular as his Guardian describes him?

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —Singular! What, is he like the Colonel, Sir Andrew?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —The image of him. While at College his love of Notoriety first displayed itself, but by living entirely with English abroad, he is become as eccentric and ab∣surd as the Colonel wishes him.

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —By Jasus, you've hit it—ma foi—he is toujours wanting to get into notice, and between our three selves, he keeps me as his Valet, Frisseur, and all that, only becase I perplex, make a noise, and am quite au fait at botheration wherever I go!

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —Pray what brings Mr. Nominal so suddenly from France? Is'nt it something about an affair of honour?

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —Oui—you may say that. He is come to chal∣lenge one Clairville, for getting into the window of Madamoiselle Honoria; and to be sure he won't give the young seducer a little snug dejeune of cold lead.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —'Tis so, then—poor Clairville.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Tell us now, had you a pleasant journey?

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —Pleasant!—Oh by the eternal Powers, toute au contraire, my dear: we were stopp'd and robb'd and murder'd—that is, we should have been, but for a fine young haro who came and rescued us; Mardleu! he made them skip like frogs!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —A robbery and duel: this journey may produce much pleasing distress. Pray, who was this young hero?

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P:
—Je ne sais pas lioney—but you may talk of your Caesars, Cleopatras and Paddy Whacks; he beats all your champions of posterity. Oh! had you seen when
my master and I were sprawling, how he laid about him with his bit of timber. Depend on't, as our Fille de Chambre said, the Shillaly is the true je ne sais quoi after all!

SP.SPEAKER: Soph A
SP.P: —very extraordinary fellow, Sir Andrew—What's your name, friend.

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —Bluder O'Whack, Jontleman. The Blunders are the oldest family in Ireland—we were planted there like so many potaty's by a great General, who was af∣tewards Lord Lieutenant to King—what d'ye call the old Monarque;—Oh! King Lear—aye, that's it—King Lear.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —King Lear!

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —C'est vrais Miss; and after that the family got a curst tumble about the reign of Jack Cade—pardonnez mois, though—I forget my business—I must be after informing the Colonel of his Ward's arrival.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Spare yourself the trouble Mr O'Whack, Colonel Hubbub is not here, but I'll take care to inform him.

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —Je vous remercies, my dear—but d'ye mind me now—depechez vous, and tell him my master's so particular in his person and manners, that you may hear of him any where. Monsieur good luck to you—my Lady, j'ai l'honueur, d'etre tres humble serviteur.—Oh! by my soul, the true comme il faults better than whiskey.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —If the servant is a picture of the master, No∣minal will have too much good humour to quarrel with Clairville. Faith! I almost love him by description. But I must leave you, Guardy—Adieu.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Nay don't hurry, my angel; it's too soon for the dying scene.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —I know it, but first I'm going to see a friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —See a friend—then pray let me go with you, for that's a thing I never saw in my life.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE—the Park.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter O'WHACK with Books under his arm.

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —By St. Dennis! these law Gentlemen are as heavy—I wonder what my Master would be after with them, ce'ne fait rien, I must take them home as he or∣der'd me.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter SAUNTER (Spying and looking out at Nominal.)

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —Astonishing! I never saw so strange a looking figure in my life, who can it be! [turning round sees O'Whack, who bows to him] He! O'Whack, how came you here! what is your Master, my old college friend, re∣turn'd from his travels.

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —Oui your honour, et la Voila! there he is!

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —What yonder! well! this is excellent! I knew Nominal always lov'd singularity, but I never thought he'd make himself so particular, that his friends should not know him.

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —C'ette extraordinaire my dear, but with all his oddities, you can't help loving him—Oh! his heart is as warm as l'eau de vie, and his soul, by St. Patrick! the rest of the world's all blarney to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Ah Saunter my dear follow, well, what do you think? won't it do? shan't I take!—heh!—hark'ye, I have them already.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —Have! whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Every body you dog, every body! I've got a name, they stare at me, point at me, laugh at me every where, a'nt I a happy fellow, heh!

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —If happiness consists in being laughed at, you are, but Nominal—would'nt it be as well, to be known for being rational, as being ridiculous.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Rational! pshoo! a plain sensible man, is never thought of now, who the devil ever thinks or cares about such a sober, honest fellow as you, who pay every body, and offend nobody, but I now, such a rogue as I who pay nobody, and offend every body, why they all like me, they court me as a new acquaintance, not cut me as an old friend, my boy!

SP.SPEAKER: Saun.
SP.P: Well, every man in his way, for my part I detest singularity.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Then you're an undone man; for by being sin∣gular in nothing, you'll be despis'd in every thing, for instance now George, when you go into company, and inquisitive people say, "who is he? what Mr. Saunter," nobody can describe you, you have been guilty of no absurdities, no improprieties! but when I condescend to enter a room, there's a general buz of applause, and the women all whisper, "that's he! the famous Ned Nominal! who games, who drinks, who sights, who intrigues! Oh! the sprightly vicious fellow!" In short, George, I'm a public character!

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —A public character! what then?

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Why then I make a damn'd noise without any meaning.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun.
SP.P: Believe Nominal you are deceiv'd, a character so useless, can neither excite admiration or attention.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Useless! oh George! George! how little dost thou know of modern life! useless! that's the very thing that makes me! now let me put a plain and sim∣ple question to you, is'nt a cat that walks on four legs an useful animal?

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —A cat on four legs useful! 'tis an odd question—certainly.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Very well! and what do you think of a cat with only two legs! why it's useless; and yet you and the rest of the world, shall give it twice the admiration and attention! and there's the difference between us George, you are a very useful worthy fellow, and con∣sequently are despis'd, I am a very useless mischievous fellow, and of course am admir'd, therefore my dear boy, take my advice; expose yourself, and get into notice.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —Why you are the counterpart of your Guar∣dian the Colonel, and when he finds you thus bitten with the love of Notoriety, he'll be delighted, transport∣ed.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Yes: but I mean to disappoint him.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —Disappoint him!

SP.SPEAKER: Nom.
SP.P: Aye; and for three reasons, George; First, because he wants me to marry Honoria, a girl I don't care for; secondly, because he has brought me to fight one Clairville, a poor Devil I never saw; and thirdly, because being in Opposition, makes more noise than being under Government—you understand me—I mean to quarrel with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —And how will you contrive it?

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —His greatest antipathy is to law and lawyers. I'll pass on him as a student.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —Student! Why you don't understand the practice.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —No; who the Devil does: but a little goes a a great way, George—so never fear.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —Well, I must leave you for the present, for I have business elsewhere. I'll see you to-morrow, and in the mean time success to your studies, your sports, and singularities.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom—[Looking after him]
SP.P: What an old fashion'd ap∣pearance! I wish I had him a little, I'd soon teach him how to expose himself—O'Whack.

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —Toujours pret, your honour,

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Take those law-books home, put them on the table, and give the room a studious appearance, for the reception of my Guardian.—You know what I in∣tend.

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —Oh! leave me alone for catching the old fox; I'll do it san's ceremonie—your honour—see who's coming this way; by my salvation it's the sweet young Haro that saved us and our chapeaus from the robbers.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —That's lucky; I want to thank him—besides if the robbery is well introduced in the papers it may give an eclat to my arrival, and some way or other I must be before the public every day.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter CLAIRVILLE, with a letter in his hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P: —Joy! give me joy, Sir; excuse this freedom from a stranger, but bliss so unexpected, so exquisite was never known before.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —What! it's all in print, is it? the whole rob∣bery! well, what do they say of me?

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P: —Oh, sir, when we parted last night I was mise∣rable; I fancied I had lost the loveliest creature the world e'er wondered at—but picture the reverse.—

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Curse the reverse; so I'm to be robbed, and get nothing by it.

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P: —In this letter she tells me, that to-night she will give me a private interview. Yes though my fa∣ther left with his title his estate to my brother and that brother has cruelly deserted me, yet at this moment I'm the happiest man alive—but excuse me, I am all haste, all anxiety to prepare for the appointment.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Hold Sir, hold;—'gad who knows but this private interview may lead to a public uproar, and as he did me a service— [aside]—Sir, I am much indebted to you, and if I can be of any use—

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P: —None in the least, I thank you. Yet, now I think ont, Honoria is so narrowly watch'd, that a friend may be necessary. He seems a Gentleman, I'll ask him— [aside]—Sir, you may assist me.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —How! how!

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P: —The Lady, sir, whose name as well as my own I must beg leave to conceal, is so much suspected by her family, that alone I may be interrupted in the interview: If therefore you will meet me at Grosvenor-Gate at ten o'clock, I will conduct you to the house, which is a short way from town. But if we are dis∣cover'd, and the business becomes public.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —When then I shall be the more obliged to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P: —Well; but if your name is brought forward and abused—

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Why then the obligation will be trebled—I like abuse, and I'll tell you why—It brings one into notice, and if somebody does not cut me up, I mean to do it myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P: —How! abuse yourself!

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Certainly; for if I don't let people know what a singular, absurd, useless sort of fellow I am, how will they find it out? Silence sinks you into obscurity, my boy; and for my part, I had rather be laughed at for standing in the pillory, than not noticed at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P: —Well! this is the strangest system—What! you want to get a name, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —I do; and Heav'n be praised, 'tis easier now to be obtained than in days of yore: then conquest, patriotism, and virtue were only paths to fame; but now a-days, eccentricity, impudence, and dissipation settle the business—and if I don't cut out Caesar or Mark Antony to-morrow!—oh my better stars to-morrow!—But come along—I have some law business with my Guardian, and after that, for you and your inter∣view.

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P: —Ten thousand thanks—but may I ask, how you intend getting a name to-morrow?

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —I'll tell you, I mean to fight a duel, commence an intrigue, and compleat an elopement! but where are the ladies, or who is the gentleman, I neither know nor can inform you; only be assured I'll accomplish it! And then, my boy, when I lack wit, I'll boast of my exploits; and when I want money—Why I'll shew myself as a public curiosity!—so allons,—and look and laugh at me while you can for nothing.

DIV3.HEAD: ACT II.
SCENE—NOMINAL'S Lodgings—Table with Books on it.

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —Blood and ounds! the Colonel will be here dans une moment. If my master had'nt l'argent enough of his own, he would'nt be after tazing his old Guardian in this manner; Voila! touteest arrange, and now to receive him a-la-mode de Francoise, as we say: in Ireland.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Colonel HUBBUB, and Sir ANDREW ACID.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel—[Dancing and singing.]
SP.P: Ti di!—di di!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Keep quiet, I tell you, Oh! curse your joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Ti di, di di!—Where is he?—the lad of spirit— the boy after his Guardian's own heart—here, here's a contract to marry him to my niece Honoria.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Be serious, I tell you: grinning does not be∣come you.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Here—this gives him my niece with thirty thousand pounds: and if he had returned a solid studious good for nothing sort of a young man, do you think I'd have signed it?—No: but to come home a dashing dog, a choice spirit!—Odds heart! if his uncle the old General was alive, he'd die with joy!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Old General, indeed!—a pretty uncle he was to leave his nephew to the care of such a Guardian as you. But I remember him: he lov'd dissipation, and despised prudence as much as yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —He did, and he appointed me Guardian to the dear boy, that I might see the glorious breed preserved! and now he's a choice spirit—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —A choice Devil. What! you want him to be a fellow, who can fight a duel in one field, and be second in another:—who drinks hard, and rides harder:—who talks much, thinks little, and reads less:— who carries off young women, and runs away from old ones:—in short, who loves Notoriety, and makes noise and confusion wherever he goes.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —That's it: you've hit it exactly: only with this difference, that though I despise prudence, I detest knavery: and if ever he behaves like a villian, if ever he does a dishonourable action, I'll cut him off with a shilling, and I know the old General would have done the same. But where is he?—Ti di, di di—O'd I'm so happy— [Offers to take snuff out of Sir Andrew's box, who refuses it.] Why what's the matter with you cousin, you don't seem to partake of my joy?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P:
—Yes I do: nothing so pleasant as to see every body on the broad grin. I hope it will last, that's all. But I know you mean to ruin him, as you have your
niece Honoria—instead of improving her mind—teach∣ing her the languages.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Her the languages!—Why old boy, hav'nt you found out that one tounge is enough for a woman. No, no; I have brought her into high life, sent her to concerts, operas—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Operas!—Now that's a pretty business: to pay a piece of gold to sit five or six hours in a house, where you fall asleep to save hearing what you don't understand.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Five or six hours!—Psha, that's nothing to what I do. I pay some thousand pieces of gold to sit seven years in another house, where I must fall asleep, for hang me, if ever I heard a word I understood!— But come, where's the boy, the heart of oak?— [Look∣ing over books on table.]—Why, what's here? a Law Dictionary!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —A Law Dictionary! something serious at last! [Reading] "Acto quinto—Jacobo primo."—No Hazard Table.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Hazard! aye, that's right: making himself master of that fine art. Law!—'sbood! if he had the least inclination for that solemn, sable profession, I'd break his bones!—I'd—but he comes, the dear profli∣gate comes! Ti di di!—my boy! my life!

DIV3.STAGE: Enter NOMINAL, in a dressing-gown, reading a book.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —C cuts off the remainder, and D loses his tail.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Come my darling, let's hear of your frolicks— mine and the General's old tricks.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom—[Still reading]
SP.P: That infernal Tail!—Ha Guar∣dian!—Sir Andrew!—both welcome—been at the Hall lately? [to Colonel.]

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Been at the Devil! Come, let's hear of your pranks?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —'Gad, if he should turn out studious after all.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Curious cause this morning—Friend Paul Prig for Plaintiff—Tell you his speech.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Why! what are you at?

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —He rose, twirl'd his band, began—"My Lord —hem! Gemmen of the Jury—hem! I'm for plaintiff— I think—I know—I've read my brief—hem!" nodding and cocking his eye to Jury.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Cocking his eye to Jury.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Yes: saves talking—"my Lord—hem I see I've a verdict,"—cocking again, "I feel—I'm right— I've done, hem!" Foreman winks, Judge sums up, verdict for Paul, client's ruin'd, all the young prigs laugh, any thing makes them laugh—hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Zounds! What is all this? Let's hear?

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Hear! never without a fee: name your Case: Joint Trustees, perhaps—if not, why not? What are your ages?

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —What are our ages?

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Infants very like.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —I an infant:—why I never was more deceiv'd in my life, Colonel, this is the most studious choice spirit I ever saw, I give you joy— [offering him snuff,] young man, this capering, grinning Gentleman, de∣scrib'd you as a perfect rake, and instead of finding you studying Coke, I expected to see you reading Hoyle: do you mean to pursue the profession?

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Certainly, student now, hereafter counsel: been at the old Baily lately?

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Old Baily! look'ye you dog, leave off this fool∣ing or—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —I'm delighted cousin! now why don't you partake my joy—faith, I must go and tell my wife and ward of this: Mr Nominal I'm sorry I'm obliged to leave you.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Leave him!—why don't you go then?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Give me your hand [to Nominal,] persevere in your studies, and I and Lady Acid shall be always happy in your company=good day, Colonel don't make long faces—he'll make full as much noise, and confu∣sion, in his present profession—though he won't fire a pistol, he can file a bill in Chancery, and which is the least mischievous I leave you to determine: Hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: —Rot you! I'm glad you're gone—now my dear boy, it's all very well to appear prudent and studious, before that stupid old fool, but since he's gone, lay aside this trifling—come, leave off talking about such low, dull nonsense, as Counsellors and Westminster Hall: and let's hear you speak like a man of sense—about fighting, drinking, racing.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom.
SP.P: —Racing! as I hope for the seals, here's the case, look!

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: —What!—do you persist in your ignorance?

SP.SPEAKER: Nom.
SP.P: —Never read Puffendorff! heh! fine book, bet∣ter than Army list.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Look'ye, I have done with you for ever, Oh! you senseless blockhead! to be making money, instead of spending it, to be following a prudent, stale, old fashion'd profession, instead of being ruin'd and getting into high life you dog! you avenge Honoria's honour! S'death! I'll beat Clairville myself, and before I hear of you, Puffendorff or Paul Prig again, I'll marry her to a drummer, or a common trooper—I will, you stupid, studious, upright rascal.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom—[Aside,]
SP.P: Now I'm satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: O'W.
SP.P: —Accoutez, your honour, the strange young haro is waiting for you at Grosvenor-gate,

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —I'll come directly, guardy adieu, brother Prig waiting.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Stay, one rational word before you go, would you—

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Hust, can't stay, reply another day, mean time find me in the hall; adieu, law's a fine profession, put's an end to grinning, transports, extacies, adieu, leave you with Puffendorff, hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P:
—Here's treatment, leave a Colonel in the Army, alone with Puffendorff, ignorant puppy; to give up fashionable life, for a profession in which the greatness of his reputation, is chiefly known by the size of his wig; where— [seeing O'Whack,] you too, you Irish,
French, pye-bald rascal, you help'd this pretty refor∣mation I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —Point de tout, your honour, your ownself could'nt have set him a more dissipated example than I did; oh! a Paris mon Colonel: to be sure I did'nt lead him into any mischief at all, at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —What do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —Tacez vous, jewel: and when I slept out all night, got drunk with usquebaugh, intrigued with the Marchioness Tipperary, and bate her poor husband, it was only to oblige your honour, and that I might stand before you and say, "voila Monsieur O'Whack, who kept it up to the last."

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Why you impertinent, do you mean to laugh at me? Marchioness Tipperary indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: James
SP.P: —Sir, Sir, a word with you, the rope ladder is again fix'd at Miss Honoria's window, and she and Miss Sophia are waiting for Mr Clairville.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Sophia with her, that's lucky, hark'ye James, is Lady Acid at home?

SP.SPEAKER: James
SP.P: —No Sir, she and Sir Andrew are just gone out together, but Miss Allirade ask'd me, whether you were expected there to-night?

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —She did! did she, oh its plain, she can't live without me, poor love-sick creature, I'll go and com∣fort her, I'll lock up Honoria, kick Clairville out of the house, and thus have her all to myself, shew me down stairs sirrah, and d'ye hear, tell your studious master, I'm gone to chastise the man, I desir'd him to challenge, Yes: I'll so shame him, by beating this Clairville—

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —Ay, by St. Patrick, bate him your honour, as I did the Marquis de Tipperary, par ici this way.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE—The outside of Sir Andrew's House in the Country.
DIV3.STAGE: SERVANT enters from House—SOPHIA appears at Window.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph—[to Servant]
SP.P: Look for Mr. Clairville where I told you, and desire him to dispatch—

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P: Where is this friend that was to have assisted in the enterprize? I have sent my servant to look for him, for alone I can undertake nothing. Oh Honoria! let me but once more see you, and know you are my friend, and I will ask no more—no, never while I live, will I think of deluding her from her family: with them, she has all that wealth and splendour can afford: and with me how severe will be the reverse? I know the Colonel has brought his Ward Nominal from France, to call me to account for my presumption; but of that I think not, let me but gain this last interview. Ha!—here comes the stranger.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —A thousand pardons. I've been talking Law, so no wonder at delay, Well, here we are—Do you know this business of your's puts me in mind of what I came to England for?

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P: —What was that?

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Oh! I only came to England to beat a gentle∣men for scaling a rope-ladder, that's all; some poor, stupid fellow. But we won't talk of that—Where's the girl? heh.

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P:
—'Tis past the time she promised to appear at the window. But understand me, Sir, all I wish to obtain is an interview, to know if she approves of my past conduct, and takes an interest in my future; there∣fore, what I request of you is this: while I guard the
house within, you watch the door without. Don't let a soul enter.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Me!—I'll beat the watch, kick the consta∣bles, and cane all the trading Justices in town, before you shall lose one tender moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —Sir,—Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P: —Ha! she comes. Like a new world she breaks upon me; oh! let me fly to welcome her.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Oh! let me fly to welcome her, [mimicking.] Now who she is, or who the house belongs to, or what it all means, hang me if I know or care; only this, that if there was a noise, there might be a discovery, if a discovery a pursuit, if a pursuit a rescue; and then—oh what a sigure I should cut.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —Come in instantly, or you may be discovered.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom—[to Clairville]
SP.P: Hark'ye, if you are discovered, and are afraid to mention your own name, make use of mine; I'm not asham'd of this or any business.

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P: —I have no fears [opening the door] now, now, Sir, envy me.

STAGE.HI: [Gets in at the door and disappears,]

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Envy you—that I do—he'll have all the fame to himself, and I stand as melancholy as a mile∣stone. How provokingly quiet every thing is here—'sdeath, is there no noise to wake the old Guardian? Is there no noise? Oh, for the squeaking of a child, the smashing of a lamp, or the howling of a husband, being beat by his wife—no uproar.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —Sir—as you are anxious to assist your friend, will you be kind enough, to tell my servant who is some where near, to come home—for if he is observ'd—

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —I will Madam—who the devil's she now?

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —And Sir, when you return, I'll speak to you from the window, and on your answering me, I'll come down, and let the servant in myself

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Ay: and me along with him. I'll take care ma'am, I'll take care, stand by Ragamuffin.

STAGE.HI: [Runs against Colonel Hubbub who is entering.]

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Stand by Ragamuffin, what noisy fellow's that? ay, there it is, there's the ladder sure enough; and I dare say Sophia has promoted the scheme, in hopes of assisting her amour with me; sweet, tender soul; I shall never forget her telling me, that if I'd one more hair on my left eyebrow, I should be the handsomest man in the guards; and another time when she fainted away, on only touching the tip of my Epaulette.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —Is it you sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Yes, here I am: oh! tis too much.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —I'll come down, and open the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Open the door, there; she wants to be touch∣ing the tip of the Epaulette again; poor, fond crea∣ture; yes, I must—I will—

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —Come in; [sees Colonel,] Heav'ns; the Colo∣nel?

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Excess of joy dissolves—don't give way to your raptures, most angelic—I come to give you love for love.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —Unhand me Colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Let's enter the house, I'll lock up Honoria, turn Clairville out of doors, and then—

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —Let me go this moment—

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Ha! what are you at? retire Madam. [Sophia enters house.] now answer me seducer—would you delude the innocent?

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —I delude!—who the deuce are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —A justice of peace!—come to promote tran∣quility, —but your name, your profession, speak this instant, [shaking him,] Zounds, do you suspect my of∣fice?

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —No—not in the least, I know you're a peace officer, by the curst noise you make;— [Nominal shakes him again.] gently, and to satisfy you, I'll tell you who I am—my name's Hubbub, I'm a Colonel in the Army.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Hubbub!

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Yes, I'm here doing duty.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —My guardian,—faith, this is better than Paul Prig.

SP.SPEAKER: Clair—[Aside to Nominal.]
SP.P: Detain him—keep him where he is, or all's ruin'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —I will, [Clairville exit from window.] Sir, [bow∣ing,] if your name is Hubbub, I have to entreat your pardon—I've the honour of being acquainted with part of your worthy family.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Ay, ay, I knew you'd perceive your mistake—but let me enter the house, and play the devil.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom—[Holding him.]
SP.P: Yes Colonel: I have the pleasure of being intimate with your very learned Ward Mr. Nominal; times are strangely alter'd, Sir—I remember when he was the most noisy, extrava∣gant young man in town.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Ay, those were happy days: but they're all over now. The dog thinks of nothing but Puffendorff and the old Baily.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Yes: I us'd to have a warrant against him once a week, and he generally slept in the watch-house every other night; but now—alas Colonel! I'm afraid we shall never catch him in a riot again.

SP.SPEAKER: Col—[Sighing.]
SP.P:
No—he has loft all that good sense and genius now; and after the pains I had taken
in instructing, and improving him, it's hard; very hard, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom—[Sighing with him.]
SP.P: Ay, Sir: to have him turn out studious, sober and prudent.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Ah! to disgrace the honour of the Hubbubs, to vilify the glorious breed;—stupid, senseless dog!—but let me go, for I'm all eagerness to chastise this Clairville.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Clairville!—what's he now in the house?

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Yes; and I brought my Ward Nominal to fight him; but he dar'nt Sir—he's grown a coward, a poor paltry priggian coward, and if you see him, you may tell him I say so.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —So!—I may tell Nominal he's a coward, may I?

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Yes: or he'd have beat somebody before this time—o'd rot him, I would rather he'd have can'd me than nobody—

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —You'd not dislike to be can'd by him; would you?

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —No, I should have lik'd the dear rouge the better for it—but now I know him to be such a mean studious pitiful puppy, that hang me, if I think he has the courage to beat a jack-ass.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom—[Caning him]
SP.P: He'll beat a Jack-ass with any man in the army.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Holloo! what are you about?—

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —You're a ruffian, a common bravo, employed by Clairville to detain and assault me, and you take ad∣vantage of my not having a sword on, but I'll be re∣veng'd—

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Do—and I'll tell you how; bring an action of battery, and Paul Prig and your studious nephew shall defend it—hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P:
—I don't care, you're beneath my contempt, but for your employ'r, I'll enter the house, and have satis∣faction, and for that sneaking dog Nominal—oh the
curst puppy; I sent for him to bear Clairville, and here have I been beat myself!

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P: —My dear Sir, once more let me thank you—I have seen the Lady, and all is, as I wish'd. She has given me this picture, as a proof of her affection, and promis'd never to marry another man.—But come —why, what are you thinking?

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —I was thinking when this business is found out, what a noise it will make; but hold—hold—you and I must have some conversation.

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P: —The Lady told me what I never heard before, that her Uncle's Ward is design'd for her husband.—

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —What Nominal! I know him intimately, nor is there a finer fellow alive; he pricks the bladder of vanity, pulls down arrogance, and chastises folly, and what's more, he gives his Guardian sound law in the morning, and a sound thrashing at night; then he's a man of Notoriety, has the general shout—the popular huzza, my boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P: —Popular huzza! he'd have that, if he was go∣ing to be hang'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Well! and when I die, give me a public exit! —give me the Tower, state trial, axe, scaffold and decapitation! then my life or history will be written, with a thousand extraordinary anecdotes; how I slept at night, and woke in the morning! walk'd and rode, eat and drank, and what was very remarkable and im∣portant, wore my own hair till thirty, and a wig ever after.—But come along, I'll introduce you to Nominal; and over a bottle, he shall convince you, that he's as popular, as life, spirit, and eccentricity can make him.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE—An Apartment at Sir Andrew's—House.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —Never was vanity so insufferable, as that of Sir Andrew and the Colonel; and unless my Cousin Sophia, puts my scheme in execution, they will tor∣ment her for ever—here comes Sir Andrew, just as I left him, teizing and fatiguing her, with his tiresome protestations of love.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter SOPHIA follow'd by Sir ANDREW.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —Do—leave me Sir Andrew—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Well! but hear me my little angel; I see your passion for me, and your aversion to the Colonel, and I pity you, and will relieve you: hark'ye, make an assignation, nay, don't be afraid, I'll not disappoint you, upon my soul.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —Sir Andrew this is beyond bearing, and if you would attend Lady Acid's concert, where your company is wanted, it would be more agreeable—assig∣nation indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Ay: you know I've won your tender little heart, and that I could make you miserable if I pleased, but I forego it, I chuse to vex the Colonel and—

SP.SPEAKER: James
SP.P: —Sir, the concert is waiting.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Concert! psha! curse all harmony say I; but I must go to please my wife. I say, don't forget Sophia, when and where you like, I'll be punctual, tell when, farewell, and may you never know the iron—

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —Provoking! to suppose me in love with him! I that am admir'd by the literati, the cognoscenti, and all the out of the way creatures in town; here, (giving Saunter a letter,) look at this, and then say, if I ought'nt to be as wretched as a new Tragedy.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun —(reading,)
SP.P: “Lady Acid informs Miss Strangeway, that her extraordinary attachment to the Colonel and Sir Andrew, is the talk of the whole town, that she has lost her character, and unless she discontinues her advances, she shall be sent to the country and lock'd ”up for life.—Lock'd up for life!

SP.SPEAKER: Soph—[mournfully.]
SP.P: Ay, lock'd up for life!— think of that cousin, I that have painted my own picture, and had it in the exhibition! that can read a Latin Virgal, or a French Rabelis; and what's more, that have written a novel which has been translated into several languages.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —Has it been translated into English?

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —I too, who have written and compos'd a song, which I have sung in every company, without being ask'd or desir'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —Why you have an universal genius indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —Universal! I dare say my death will encrease the National debt; for after being under ground with my ancestors, I shall be pull'd up and reburied at the expence of my country; and after all this, to have my reputation slander'd by two old coxcombs, and what's worse, to be sent to the country and lock'd up for life! oh cousin! what can I—shall I do?

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —Don't be unhappy Sophia, I have thought of a scheme by which you may expose the vanity of these two dotards, and extricate yourself. [Giving her two letters] read these two letters, and if you approve, copy them.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph—[reading]
SP.P: “To Sir Andrew Acid—Thou gay deceiver— I adore—ten o'clock—your ”own garden—Sophia Strangeway. Fie, cousin! would you have me send him an assignation in reality,—

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —Read the other.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: — “To Colonel Hubbub. Thou dear perfi∣dious —I idolize—ten o'clock—the garden—”Sophia Strangeway. Charming! I understand, both in the same language, and both at the same time and place, I'll copy 'em directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: Yes, a double assignation, then they'll meet, their exposition will be complete, and Lady Acid will be convine'd of your innocence.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —Ten thousand thanks, [goes to Table fits and writes.] "To Colonel Hubbub." So, "To Sir Andrew Acid," [rises,] There, Cousin, [giving him letters,] see them deliver'd, and meet me in the garden —at present, adieu!

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —Nay, where are you hurrying to?

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —First to the concert, and after that, to—but now I recollect, don't forget your promise of intro∣ducing me to your friend Nominal: heigh-ho! I'm in love with him only for his dress.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —How Sophia! judge of a man by his dress!

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —Certainly; if I see a man plainly dress'd, I guess him to be just such a harmless good for nothing as yourself; but if I see a man dress'd unlike all others, then I know him to be the same unaccountable creature I am myself; so save me from rural imprisonment, and then introduce me to your sigular friend as soon as you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —How can I deliver the letters? to avoid sus∣picion, the best way would be to give them to Sophia's own maid, and if I can find her—

SP.SPEAKER: O'W—[advancing.]
SP.P: What, Fanny, your honour! arrah, I am just going to her, donnez mois le Billet doux, and if I don't put them into her own ruby hands, say this is not No. 13, that's all!

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —Are you sure you know her?

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —Know her!—accoutez, my dear, she loves me so tenderly, that she'd go to Kilkenny for a fricassee for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —Well! I believe I may trust you; here, this is for Sir Andrew, and this for Colonel Hubbub, they are both at the concert, and desire her to deliver them directly.

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: Si vous plait, honey.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —And d'ye hear, tell her to bring me the an∣swers, you understand me.

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —Bon sois, your honour, [Saunter exit.]—By the pow'rs, some people know no more of good breed∣ing, than others do of Politesse. Eh, bien! I suppose it answers—for I've observ'd, none jog so snugly through life, as your completely rude and vulgar—every body gets out of the way for them, the same as a gentleman in a white coat would for a chimney sweeper, Oh, by the powers, the only place for true etiquette is Ireland, sweet, elegant, accomplished Ireland.

STAGE.HI: Saloon, Chandeliers, James, and other Servants waiting.

SP.SPEAKER: James
SP.P: —Yau! [yawning,] these parties will be the death of me; what! none of the musical nobility come yet! stand by, here's Lord Jargon! 'gad I like his plan, he makes love to Lady Acid, to secure Miss Honoria; the old Lady, for the young one, but mum!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —Am I the first, James? I though your concert began at eight.

SP.SPEAKER: James
SP.P: —No my Lord, this is our Sunday concert, and it is generally nine before their Lordships begin playing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —Lordships! ah! true, at these Sunday con∣certs, Lords become fidlers, and fidlers greater men, for my part, I cannot play or sing, "donne, donne."

SP.SPEAKER: James
SP.P: —Thus it ever is with his Lordship, one word contradicting the other.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —James, where's Lady Acid? ha! my Lord Jargon here.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —Honoria, my angel, I never say a civil thing, but you look divinely this evening. Nay: why avoid me, am I so very disagreeable?

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —Not in the least my Lord—where can be Lady Acid?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar—[taking her hand.]
SP.P: You know. Honoria. I hate to hear people talk of themselves—of their titles—their fortune—their talents—nothing can be so shocking!—now I—I have an antient title—great fortune, and not inferior talents, but I never mention these things, you never hear me talk of my∣self.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —No your Lordship has too much sense, to talk on a subject you so little understand.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —True, Honoria: and I have reform'd—left off all my old vices, the better to deserve your af∣fection—gaming now—I hav'nt thrown a die, or made a bett these six months.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —Not gam'd my Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —No—I'll bett any gentleman two hun∣dred to one, I hav'nt.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —I fancy your Lordship is one of those, who think it better to lose, than not play at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —No—I have given it up Honoria—but talking of gaming—allow me to apologize for breaking your bracelet last night.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —It was of no consequence my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —Your pardon Honoria—and though I'm above making presents, yet you must allow me to offer this poor return—these jewels—

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —How! jewels!—and of such value my Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —Oh a trifle—for my own part I never wear diamonds—for while other people wear them for me to look at, it's just the same as if they were my own—but think not of them, but love my angel—

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —Excuse me my Lord—I cannot accept them—you may employ them to a better purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Is this your gratitude for his Lordship's politeness?—ill-bred, insolent girl!—what, you are still hankering after that wretch Clairville.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —Call him by some other name, madam—wretch!—what is his brother then?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —How!—have you the impudence to de∣fend the outcast?

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —Out cast!— shame, shame, madam!— I know I talk a language, you and your modest friends despise—but here I tell you that this outcast is the man of my heart—that it loves him tenderly loves him! and would rather share his griefs in a prison, than his Lordship's pleasures in a palace—therefore once more, let me offer back your present—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Look'ye—in a word—let me have no more of your ill-breeding; accept his Lordship's jewels directly, and retire to your chamber—take them I say, and begone this instant.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —What can I do?—the Colonel's high opinion of her, compels me to obey her in every thing—Oh Clairville!—why did you save a life that's doom'd—for ever doom'd, to mix thy ruin with its own.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —So far, so well my Lord—for when the Colonel hears she was mercenary enough to receive jewels, he'll own you were warranted in your designs upon her—and now—since we are alone—I'll open a great and glorious scheme—a scheme that shall convince you of my unalter'd affection.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —Sweetest of women: you know my deter∣mination, whoever has my hand, you still have my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P:
—I believe it my Lord, and therefore I shall risk the dangerous enterprize; Sophia and I were a the exhibition of wax figures this morning, she was
struck with, and purchas'd a great theatrical likeness, which is to be brought here in a chair this evening, now if you contrive to come home instead of the figure.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —I a wax figure: a Peer of the Realm a wax figure!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Dear: it happens every day; but mind me, the chair will be brought into my dressing room, which adjoins Honoria's chamber, and where you know you can't be admitted on account of Sir Andrew's jealousy—therefore, wait for the chair—bribe the men—and here is a false key, [giving one,] which locks and unlocks Honoria's door—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —Loveliest of creatures!— [Kissing her hand] where shall I find the chair?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —I'll give you the particulars bye and bye—in the mean time, remember you get Clairville dis∣posed of.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —What! my brother:—Oh, I've so great a friendship for him that I'll have him arrested, to pre∣vent his being extravagant.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Hark!—their Lordships the musicians are arrived.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —There they are: never was Sunday concert so sanctified with nobility.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —What! they're all come!

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Yes: and saith, there's so many great people turned fidlers, now-a-days, that may I die, if I should be surpris'd, if the house of Lords was changed into a concert room:—that glees were sung from the Wool∣sack.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —Who have we amongst us Colonel?

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P:
—Ill tell you—first there's Duke Duett playing on the violin—then there's General Gig blowing the trumpet, Judge Jerk blowing the bassoon, and Bishop
Bravo banging the kettle drums;—but what's better, there's Signor Uniquo, who pats them all familiarly on the back and says. "Bravissimo my Lord Judge! encore Signor Bishop!"—then the one looks as pleased, as if he'd got the Chancellorship, and the other as if he was prefer'd to an Archbishopric!—pray is your Lord∣ship fond of music?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —Me!—I hate—I detest it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Hate music my Lord!—dear!—dear! I always thought it was one of your favourite amuse∣ments.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —What, music!—oh certainly, I love it of all things.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Well: for my part I shall not listen to their Lordships, till Uniquo gets them engaged at the Opera—as to you Lady Acid, I know your sense and virtue despises this trifling folly; and you only promote it to amuse your friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —I do indeed Colonel— [Strumming of In∣struments within.] I must go and look at them, come my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar—[taking her hand.]
SP.P: With pleasure;—Colonel, is my friend Nominal amongst them?

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —My Ward!—zounds, don't talk of him—but go—and if you wish for fiddling preferment, pay your respects to the grand Signor.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —My Ward indeed!—Oh! that stupid, stu∣dious puppy; I know what it will end in:—he'll go sneaking on in his profession, till he gets into the upper house—there he'll be laid on the shelf, and go out like the snuff of a candle—as to that ruffian and the assault, I'll be reveng'd on Clairville still—for Lady Sophia, the dear creature seems fonder of me than ever, since last night's riot; the women do love a little rude∣ness now and then.

SP.SPEAKER: Jame
SP.P: —Sir—Miss Sophia's maid is below and de∣sires to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —There, I said so, oh! I and my Epaulette play the devil with the women.

SP.SPEAKER: James
SP.P: —She has a letter for you Sir, that she will de∣liver to nobody but yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Well! if it must be so—it's very strange, what can make the sex adore me so passionately! it must be my manners, my tender, graceful insinuating man∣ners: shew me to her, and while their Lordships are fiddling for the good of the Nation, I'll amuse myself for the benefit of Sophia, poor Sophia!—oh Colonel Colonel, what fools do you make of the women!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE—Sir Andrew ACID's Garden—Moonlight.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —Where can my cousin Sophia be loitering?—this is the place of Assignation, and I see neither her, nor the Colonel, nor Sir Andrew.—I hope there's no mistake; for on their exposition depends her fu∣ture happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —Oh cousin! my dear cousin, I'm undone! as much ruin'd as if I'd never been an authoress, or an actress, or a painter, or a—

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —Why, what has happened?

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —Lady Acid unknown to Sir Andrew has read the assignation you made me send him; she is now con∣vinced the love is on my part, and is pursuing me here to be reveng'd. Dear me, I wish I had'nt written to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —Not written to him!—unless you put a stop to his or the Colonel's vanity, you know you'd have been sent to the country; nay, lost your character, and never shewn your face in fashionable life again.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P:
—Not shewn my face! Lord!—it rather helps one, and in fashionable life, loss of character makes ones reputation noticed. But what is to become of me?
If I am sent to the country I shall die; I know I shall and so suddenly, I shan't have time to write my own life, and run down half my acquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A—[Without]
SP.P: Where is the Jezabel? I'll make an example of her.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —Here she comes, and I shall be lock'd up in an old country castle, where there's a constant knock∣ing at the gate to see the apartments, but not a person to enquire after— "Poor I the prisoner."

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: So Miss—notwithstanding the warning I gave you, you have been writing an assignation to my husband, and this is the place. Look at me—answer me— do you deny it?

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —No, Madam: I own that I wrote assignations to both the Colonel and Sir Andrew—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: — The Colonel too! Mercy on me, would'nt one content you?

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —Yes, Madam; but I did it to bring them toge∣ther, and laugh at them; for indeed they have so teiz'd me—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —They teiz'd you! Here's effrontery! Look'ye I know they hate and depise you; and they have both told me a thousand times that your love was trouble∣some and disgusting.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —Your Ladyship, I can contradict that, for I have now in my pocket both their answers to Sophia's assignation; each accepts her invitation, and will be here at the time appointed. Besides, you must be sensi∣ble that her loving them is a joke.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Joke! Don't tell me of jokes, Sir; I never made one in my life, and I know she loves them as much as they detest her: its all owing to her romantic turn of mind, her acting, her writing—

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —Nay, my Lady; don't abuse my talents. Did'nt my last production go through four editions?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P:
—Yes; and why did it?—because it was patronized; and now-a-days it is not the book itself,
but the name of the person who writes it! While a woman of fashion shall write a bad work, and have a thousand subscribers, a poor neglected man of genius shall write a good one, and not have a single patrons If indeed you had followed my advice—written sen∣timentally and morally.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: I did, Madam: I did write morally, and what was the consequence? I had made a sum of money by a Novel called "Seduction," and I lost it all by writ∣ing "An Essay on Charity!" But indeed Sir Andrew and the Colonel are to blame: and if you'll wait a mo∣ment you'll see them come to the assignation.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —They come!—they know better: besides despising you, they value my good opinion too highly to trifle with it in this manner; so retire to the country.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —Pray hear reason, Madam—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —I'll hear nothing [Sees Sir Andrew with∣out] Bless me! what do I see?—my husband caper∣ing and smiling!

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —Aye, there's one of them; and see, Madam, yonder is the other.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —The Colonel, as I live—This is amazing! Stand back, and let's observe them.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir ANDREW, with a letter in his hand,
Enter Colonel HUBBUB, with a letter in his hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A—[Reading and smiling.]
SP.P: Thou gay deceiver!

SP.SPEAKER: Col—[Reading and smiling.]
SP.P: Thou dear perfidious!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir
SP.P: —I adore you as much as I abhor the Colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: I idolize you as much as I despise Sir Andrew.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph—[Coming between them close to Colonel.]
SP.P: My pretty Colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —There!

STAGE.HI: [Turning from her in great joy and put∣ting up his letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph—[Coming up to Sir Andrew.]
SP.P: My charming Baronet.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —My angel!

STAGE.HI: [The Colonel embraces her on the other side—they see one another—Sophia stands laughing between them.]

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —For shame! for shame! Is this your boasted honour, at your time of life? "Thou dear Perfidious!" — [Colonel Exit.]—And you—what have you to say for yourself "Thou gay Deceiver!"

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: Say! [Tearing letter.] Why, when one's com∣pletely miserable, nothing is so pleasant as to see a friend in the same situation—Holloo, Colonel!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Sophia, I'm now convinced of your inno∣cence, and ask your pardon; and will make you amends by reading your manuscripts, praising your acting, and saying you're so good a letter-writer, that I believe you're the author of Junius.

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P: —My distresses croud on me so fast, that I will see my brother once more; and if he still avoids me, I must banish Honoria from my thoughts, and seek that peace abroad, my enemies deny me here.

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —Run—fly; make your escape your honour, arrah! be off, before the Coquins lay hold of you; by my salvation when I think of your misfortunes, I can't help taking out my mouchoir.

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P: —What is the matter O'Whack?

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —The matter! why if you don't scamper, you'll be Bastil'd, before you can say, "Killarnev."

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P: —What can this mean?—explain.

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —Douceent! I'll tell you, as I pass'd yonder promenade, an old friend of mine, who is an officer, or bailiff d'ye see, old me, he was coming to carry your honour to prison. "What! Monsieur Clairville," says I. "The same." says he—then says I, "be asy now; for by St. Patrick, if you touch a hair of his head. I'll soupmaigre you this instant,"—says he, "I must do my duty;"—"and I mine," says I — and re∣member “my honey, it's as asy to have pity in your heart, as it is to spake French without the brogue ”ma foi!—this often'd him your honour, and he promis'd to be a chere Amis to you till to morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P: —Thaks, my good fellow, thanks.—

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —est ne pas tout though—Fanny, Miss Sophia's maid, as pretty a Fille de Chambre as ever made a faux pas—gave me a bit of a him, that there was a curst black business in the wind, between your brother Lord Jargon, and Lady Acid: she thinks, they mean to put you in Limbo, becase Madamoiselle Honoria loves you; and by my soul, if they do, I'll make the old cat cry "Misericorde," till she's black in the face.

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P: —I won't believe it, I know Lord Jargon loves Honoria, but I can never think, that, on that account, he'd make a pisoner of his brother: but he's coming this way, I'll talk to him, leave us together.

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: That I will, with all my heart and soul, for I can't bear to put my eyes upon him, bon Repos your honour, I'll give you a call in the morning, and in the mean time be debonnaire d'ye see, I'll carry you through depend on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P: —My kind fellow—how shall I repay you?

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —Oh your honour, I never forget an obligation or an injury, you sav'd me in danger, and if I don't do mon possible to bother all your enemies, say I'm not the bonne bouche of the O'Whacks, that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P: —I cannot, will not, suspect him of such treach∣ery, though he has been long dead to brotherly affec∣tion, he never can be capable of such inhumanity.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar—[Aside.]
SP.P: This poor wretch here!—I was in hopes he was dispos'd of,

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P: —Brother, a word, I have a favour to entreat of you, for necessity, extreme necessity compells me; in short, if you do not assist me, I shall be arrested in an hour, and in goal perhaps the rest of my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —Arrested! who can be so hard-hearted Harry? you know my friendship, and liberality, but as to lending you money, that's a thing I can't make up my mind to.

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P: —The sum I require is small my Lord, a few hundreds will convey me far from the persecution of my creditors, and by retirement and oeconomy, in a few years perhaps I shall be able to repay you with ho∣nour, and once more appear in the world as your Lord∣ship's brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —I hope you may Harry, but petitions are so numerous.—

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P: —Petition! 'tis my demand Sir; when the old Lord died, you know he left his fortune to you, in the full conviction, you would provide for me—and this is the return! while you are affluent enough to squan∣der thousands in the whirlpool of fashion, you are cruel enough to see a brother waste his life in poverty: but go on my Lord, exult and riot in my father's riches, I will be prouder of his virtues.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —Oh, the old cant: you never heard me utter a sentiment in your life, never, for the man who boasts of virtue and feeling, seldom practises either the one or the other; but you detain me Harry, I am going to sigh away an hour with Honoria.

SP.SPEAKER: Clair—[Eagerly.]
SP.P: With Honoria, brother!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —Yes: With Honoria, brother! don't you envy me my triumph?

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P: —Ungenerous man! is it not enough to abandon me to the world, a beggar and a wandeter, but you must wound me in the tenderest point, distract me with such thoughts! but I have done; farewell. my Lord, per∣haps we shall never meet again! I now suspect him, and will warn Honoria of her danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —Adieu Harry, shall I tell the charming girl any thing about you.

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P: —Yes Sir, tell her, pursued by enemies, and de∣serted by my friends. I know not where to fly for safe∣ty; tell her, not so much on my own account I lament my misfortunes, as on hers; since abject and forsaken as I am, I cannot shelter or protect her; tell her, I once hop'd, forgive my weakness— [Weeping,] but if you have one spark of pity for the lost Clairville, bestow it on Honoria—be her friend, and you shall still be mine—farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —Ay: go your ways, you'll never see her again, for here comes the chair that gives me possession of her for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —Sit it down, and wait till I return—I must step over to my house, to order servants to be near at hand; for though I'm determin'd not to be vio∣lent, yet if she demurs I'll force her!—I'll—

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Ha, Peer; my boy, how are you: I hate wine but I've been drinking to keep up my character, and I'm the most unlucky dog alive; I've been searching every where for an adventure, and can't find one: I can't get into notice.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —Can't you?

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P:
—No—I can't make myself conspicuous; and yet I've been absurd, particular, and noisy—but what signifies; every body else is the same: the whole
town's so ridiculous, that to be star'd at, a man should be as quiet, and as dull as—a simile; heh, Peer.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —How can you drink? I hate it, if I in∣dulged myself in such odious customs, do you think I should be a favorite with the women?

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Favorite with the women! ah, there's the rub! if I could get the fame of an intrigue, or an elopement, or any other sweet impropriety—Oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —Intrigue or elopement! um—

SP.SPEAKER: Nom—Um
SP.P: —Why, what's the matter with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —Look'ye, Nominal, nothing is so shocking as to impart secrets, or boast of ladies favours; its what I never do, Sir; else I could tell you—

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Tell me! what?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —That I am this moment going on both an intrigue and an elopement.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —The Devil you are! Tol de roll de roll— [Dancing and singing]—Who! when! where! Open, unfold, you amiable, you surprising Senator.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —Fie: do you think I'd betray the confidence of the fair? No; if I was only to hint to you, that, that chair, that very chair, was to take me to a certain Baronet's house, instead of a Wax figure—

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Wax Figure! Go on—dispatch—I'm all on fire—Wheugh!

STAGE.HI: [Rubbing his hands and shewings signs of great joy,]

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —I say I should be the greatest rascal living, if I was only to hint that I intrigued with the Baronet's wife, that she was to conduct me to the chamber of a young lady, and that their names were—

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Hang their names—only let me understand —that chair you say, takes you to the lady with whom you intrigue, and she conducts you to the lady with whom you elope.— [Lord nods assent]— Bravo, my boy! Bravo! Give me your hand; and now curse me if I can help laughing, to think how they'll all be surprized. Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P:
No, nor I, the old husband, little thinks, who's coming to make a fool of him! Ha! ha! ha! but
excuse me a moment, I must step over the way, to or∣der servants to be near the house, stay till I return, and you'll see what a figure I'll make in the chair.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Yes: yes—I'll stay, but go over the way, get along, will you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —I say Nominal, I fancy you'd like to go in the chair instead of me!—Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Yes, that I should, Ha! ha! ha! [Lord exit.] And if I don't! if I don't perch myself in the centre of it, damn me if I know any thing of fame or notoriety! 'gad this is the luckiest hit—and therefore that no time may be lost, you two Coronet supporters! [Lay∣ing hold of Chairmen] open the chair and let me be the Peer's proxy!—take me to the Baronet's directly, or by all that's singular—

SP.SPEAKER: 1 st. Ch
SP.P: —Is the man beside himself?

SP.SPEAKER: Nom—[Shaking them]
SP.P: No trifling, here's a purse and a pistol! money or murder!—take your choice this moment.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 st. Ch
SP.P: —Take the money. Pat!—take the money.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Here you rogues! [giving purse.] and now I swear, whatever were his Lordship's designs, mine shall be harmless and honourable; all I want, is the fame of the thing!—and if I can't get that, hang me, if I'll fatigue myself or the ladies, so open the chair, and away, my boys. [Gets in and looks from window,] when you see his Lordship, tell him the next time he is going on an amour, not to mention it before-hand—lead on to Notoriety!—"drink and drive care away."

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —Now, Nominal—now you shall see what a figure I'll cut in the chair;—how! what! gone! the chair too! 'Sdeath—I cut a pretty figure indeed, but I'll be revenged, I'll follow him, and have the satisfaction directly; and for Clairville and Honoria —I'll betray one, and imprison the other; I will, as I'm a gentleman and a man of honour!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE—Lady ACID'S Dressing Room—Toilette —Doors open in Flat Scene, and part of a bed seen— chairs and candles.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —Can it be possible! can she who should protect. me, thus betray me! I will not, dare not believe it.!—and yet would Clairville terrify me with false suspicions? let me read the letter once more.

P.Q: “I have been just inform'd, that Lord Jargon and Lady Acid have designs against you, and that to night they mean to put their villiany in exe∣cution; I hope they cannot be so treacherous, but as you love my peace or your own, be on your guard ”—beware Honoria! and remember the Unhappy Clairville.

SP.P: If it be true, how shall I extricate myself?—the Colonel is so convinced of Lady Acid's honour, that all supplication to him would be in vain—alas!—I have no friend to succour or defend me; and helpless as I am—ha! she comes! I dread to meet her,

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —How!—not gone to your chamber, Honoria!

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —I'm going Madam—her very look alarms me!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —What is the girl muttering?—I declare you grow more and more forward, and impertinent every hour—but I'll humble you—I'll make an example of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon—[Kneeling.]
SP.P: Oh! on my knees let me entreat your pity; do not desert me,—do not abandon me— promise me I shall not be in the power of Lord Jargon, and I'll be your slave for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Lord Jargon!—Why what's the fool thin king of?—have you lost your senses?

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —No—not yet, Madam—but if I retain them it must be by your humanity!—you have often said that you would be a mother to me—be so now— save me in this hour of danger and—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Danger! let me here no more of this inso∣lence, but begone!

DIV3.STAGE: Enter BETTY followed by Chairmen with Chair.

SP.SPEAKER: Bet
SP.P: —The chair with the figure, your Ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Put it down and leave it. [Betty and Chairmen exeunt]—now comes my triumph! [aside.] How! not gone yet, miss!—retire this instant or—

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —I obey, madam—oh! what!—what will become of me?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —There she goes, and now for my dear— dear Lord! [Taps at the Chair window.]—Lord Jargon, Lord Jargon—come forth my dear Lord, and ensure your prize.

DIV3.STAGE: NOMINAL lets down the front glass, looks at her and nods.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Heav'ns!—what do I see?

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —No Lord or wax figure, but as lively a fellow as ever you intrigued with— [spying.]—fine jolly woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Who are you?—has his Lordship sent you to insult me?

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —No—he has sent me not to disappoint you, and I'll bring you both before the public, depend on't: — [spying again]—rather fat though.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Mercy!—There's my husband!

SP.SPEAKER: Nom—[Eagerly.]
SP.P: Your husband!—tell me my dar∣ling—tell me—is he jealous?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Jealous! to an extreme!

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —What! he'll bring an action, and sue for a divorce?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Paragraph and Caricature me!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Certainly.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Challenge and fight me!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Undoubtedly.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Huzza!—Bravo!—I'm made; I'm immortaliz∣ed, let me out, and let him in directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —In her dressing room is she? never mind, I have the privilege of going into it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —The Colonel! worse and worse!

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —My Guardian!—zounds: he must'nt discover me here.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Sir—if you have any gallantry or—

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Say no more my Dove, I'm snug, [pulling up window.] good bye, I'll make you comfortable.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Colonel, I rejoice to see you—

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —I beg pardon Madam for this intrusion, but when you know my business, I think you'll forgive me—I come to give Honoria to Lord Jargon.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Is't possible Colonel?

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Yes—I have made up my mind at last, the high opinion I have of your honour, and the great respect I entertain for his Lordship as your friend, has tempted me to sign this deed of settlement, [producing one,] which gives him Honoria with a fortune of 30,000 l.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —My dear Colonel, you delight me.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Ay, she will then be safe from the artifices of Clairville, and your virtuous wishes will be satisfied— you know I once designed her for my Ward Nominal.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Yes: but he is too dissipated and profligate.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —He profligate! why he's the most studious, stupid blockhead alive. I dare say he is now in his library poring over Puffendorff, or hemming [mimick∣ing] with Paul Prig.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Well: I never saw him Colonel, but I have heard he's the most noisy, riotous young man in town—has his amours—his—

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Amours!—I should as soon suspect your Lady∣ship of an intrigue as him noisy and riotous too; oh! that he was, I'd give him a borough to-morrow.

DIV3.STAGE: NOMINAL here raises the top of Chair and pops his head out.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Col—[Rising.]
SP.P: Zounds; what's that? [goes towards Chair] the devil! here's somebody in the Chair.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Ha! ha! you'll laugh when I tell you what it is—it's a purchase of Sophia's.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Purchase;—I swear I saw a man's head.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —A man; ha! ha! that's very good, it's a wax figure.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —A wax figure!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Yes: and as Sir Andrew knows nothing of it, I intreat you not to tell him.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Oh, I understand, what: it's to supply his place when he's out of the way, well, well,

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Fie Colonel, an't you asham'd to look at a Lady's curiosities; positively, if you don't come away, I'll have it remov'd. [Pulling him away] But how could you suppose it to be a man? suspect me of an intrigue!

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —I don't suspect you, I believe you to be all vir∣tue, tenderness, and truth.
SP.STAGE: Sir Andrew Acid without—Ay: ay: I'll tell her my∣self. My dear, Lord Jargon is below, and desires to see you directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —I'm busy Sir Andrew, let him wait.

SP.SPEAKER: Col—[Aside to Lady.]
SP.P: No, no, softly, I have a thought, is Honoria at home?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Yes: She's in the next room.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Then hark'ye, as his Lordship is below, go to him and tell my intentions, and if he approves, he shall have Honoria this very moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —I will Colonel: O Lord! here is Sir Andrew: but as you regard me, don't mention the fi∣gure; if that fellow's discover'd, my character's lost for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —So dear perfidious.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —So gay deceiver, ah Sir Andrew; you ought to blush for your inconstancy, so good, so faithful a wife as Lady Acid.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —It's very true Colonel: and if I did'nt think it would make her too happy, I'd own my errors, she is indeed all virtue, I'll tell you what, she has all your gaieties, with your Ward Nominal's prudence.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
