SP.P: —Plague take you, am I never to hear of any thing, but that stupid dog's prudence? but your wife, Sir Andrew, all her amusements are so innocent: wax now, she prefers wax to real life.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Wax!

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Yes: though she'd die before she'd have a young man in her room, I don't say she has much objection to a wax figure.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Wax figure:—why what the devil are you at?

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —I did'nt say there was one in that sedan chair, did I?

DIV3.STAGE: Sir ANDREW opens Chair. and NOMINAL walks solemnly out. between him and the Colonel—they stand astonished.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Zounds: the wax figure, is a live gallant.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Yes, and the studious Ward, is a choice spirit.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P:
—Yes: It's I guardy, who was a student in the morning, who cand you at night, who will fight that Gentleman, who intrigues with this Lady, [enter Lady
Acid,] and will elope with any body; and what's more, who rejoices to discover himself, because he ex∣poses hypocrisy, and saves an innocent girl from mi∣sery.

SP.SPEAKER: Col—[Dancing and singing.]
SP.P: Ti di di di! he has it: he has it: the rogue's the true thing after all: come to thy old Guardian's arms, let me gaze on thy dear face, there it is, the real tumultous, dashing look; you dog, you shall come into parliament to-morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Are you mad Colonel?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Ay damn me, are you mad Colonel?

SP.SPEAKER: Col—[To Lady Acid]
SP.P: But is he a real man of sense at last; will he give up Westminster hall, Puffendorff and Paul Prig, to intrigue, elope, fight a Baronet, and cane a Colonel in the Guards; oh! 'tis too much, give me joy, old boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Good night:

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Sir Andrew I insist on a hearing—

SP.SPEAKER: Nom.
SP.P: —Stay Baronet, I hope you're satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Satisfied of what?

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —That's I, and not any body else that intrigues with this all virtuous woman; upon my soul it's me, and do mention it every where, do, there's a sweet, pleasant, smiling fellow, say it's me, and we'll all get into print together.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Damnation!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Hear me, Sir Andrew, I'll follow him and explain the business directly, for you Colonel, I leave you to your delusion, and for vour prudent Ward, oh, was there ever any thing so unlucky.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Go your ways, hypocrite, and now my boy, my darling, let's into supper and crown the night with mirth and merriment; o'ds heart, what a likeness of me and his old uncle; come, for I do so long to hear the history of your pranks.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Ay: you shall hear them all from Paul Prig to the Justice, from the Peer to the wax figure, and then if you don't say, I'm as eccentric and ridiculous, as you wish me—why I'll never beat a jack-ass again at long as I live.

DIV3.HEAD: ACT V.
SCENE—Outside of Sir Andrew's House.

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —Oh, my poor master!—he's dead, butcher'd, murder'd, shot in a duel by that bourgeois Peer, Lord Jargon! Misericorde! Misericorde! What shall I do to bring him to life again?—I'll go home—I'll—

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —So O'Whack—Lord Jargon has called out my friend Nominal, in consequence of the affair at Lady Acid's.

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —C'est vras, your honour—and he'll never go out again—it est mort.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —How!

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —He's dead—dead as King Lear.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —Astonishing! Who told you this?

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —Myself, my own sad self! I always said when Mr. Nominal went out to fight a rencontre—

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —What?

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —That he was too much of a Gentleman to come home alive again. Oh, he and Denis O'Whack are one for that! But your Honour, is there no way of restoring him, of putting a little breath into him!

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —Ridiculous—you know nothing of the mat∣ter I see, and I am all anxiety to hear the issue of this unhappy duel.

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —Et mois aussi—and I'll go home and wait for his relicts. Oh, he's dead—he's dead—and here am I, a solitaire in the wide world by myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —Where can I gain intelligence? I have a thou∣sand fears for my friend. Lord Jargon I know is full of animosity, and Nominal is too fond of fame to make him an apology. Poor fellow—if he should be killed or even wounded—

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Wounded—why here I am George; as sound and as merry—wounded, oh you dull dog.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —Iull—why from your servant's account, I might have supposed you were dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Dead! pshoo! do you think I don't know better? Hark'ye, since we're alone I'll let you into the secret. Lord Jargon wanted to challenge me, but could'nt summon up courage; so sooner than lose the glory of a combat with so great a man, I consented to — [whispering him]—you understand me. We fought to satisfy the town, not ourselves.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —Satisfy the town—how do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —How do I mean—why do you think we fought to please ourselves? Nonsense—that's been gone by long ago. No, no; the case was this—he was compelled to fight to save his reputation, and I chose to fight to get a name—so we kept up appearances—measured ground—we exchang'd shots—our seconds interfered, applauded our spirit, signed the report, and now we're both men of honour as long as we live—there, you rogue, shot ourselves into nonce.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —Bravo; and while the world is sanguinary enough to compel those to bleed like heroes who wish to live like men, why you and his Lordship may glory in having trick'd them. But since my cares on our account are over, allow me to enquire at this house after my cousin Sophia. Poor girl, Sir Andrew has be∣haved to her in a manner so cruel and inhuman—

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —Cousin, cousin, I'm lock'd up; I can't get out. Sir Andrew has confined me in this room till he sends me to the country for life.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Here's a pretty business.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —What! he was offended at the sham assignation, was he?

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —So he says; but I know it is all owing to his wife; he is so out of humour with her, that he must be revenged on somebody. Cousin, won't you assist me? Will you let me be buried in woods, and waste my youth with fat calves and sucking pigs?

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —No; before you shall an hour, I'll kill all the fat calves and sucking pigs in England. Fair Lady, if your cousin don't release you, I will. 'Gad I was only thinking of an elopement, and pop she comes to my purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —Be patient, Sophia; I'll go directly to the Colonel, and request his interference with Sir Andrew. But hush, the old tyrant's coming this way; shut down the window, and depend on my protection.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —And on mine, sweet Excellence.— [Sophia disappears.] — Faith, that is the luckiest house—last night I helped a gentleman into it, and to day perhaps I may hand a lady out of it. I'll have her, whoever she is. My dear Saunter, tell me what's her name?

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —Don't you know her? It's Sir Andrew's Ward, Sophia: a great authoress and private actress.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —A private actress: that's a public character, then there's a pair of us, and if we elope, we shall alarm all Europe.

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —She has heard of you Nominal, and between ourselves, has a great prepossession in your favour; she loves singularity, and is consequently so fond of your character—

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —There, I said it would happen—the moment I'got the fame of a duel, and an intrigue, I knew no woman could stand me: but George, my boy, how can I see her? speak to her? is there no way?

SP.SPEAKER: Saun
SP.P: —None unless you can prevail on her Guardian; here he is, try him, for my part I'll to the Colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —I will, I'll try him George, and if I can but coax him into an interview— [Exit Saunter.] I'll hu∣mour him, give him a touch in his own way.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Plague on them all I say, but chiefly that devil incarnate; that Nominal.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Sir Andrew, I want to ask a favour of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Do you? I never grant any sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Nay, you don't know me Sir Andrew, if you did, you'd grant me any thing—I am a man after your own heart, [in a melancholy voice,] I am indeed: so out of humour with the world, that like you, I wish to see every body in it, as miserable as myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —You do! do you!

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Yes indeed Sir—and if you knew how misantropically I spent my time, oh, I once pass'd such a happy day Sir Andrew; exactly in your way— I'll tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Exactly in my way!

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Yes Sir, I woke at five, and saw a neighbour's houe on fire; was second in a duel at six, and my man lost the tip of his ear—din'd at four, and something in the wine, that made six of my best acquaintance sick, drank tea, and intrigued with my friend's wife till eight, a fat Lady, went to the new comedy; saw it completely damn'd, sup'd with the poor devil of an Author: and to conclude, lodg'd six of the Actors in the round-house!—there, was'nt that a happy day? and now, will you let me see your Ward?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: See Sophia, zounds! neither you nor any body else shall ever see her again:—that chaise, [point∣ing to one without.] is waiting to take her to the country directly, and she shall live and die in an old castle on a brown moor.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Shall she?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Yes: I'll be reveng'd on her for you all; and so your servant,

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P:
—Stay, thou dear connoisseur in wax figures, and tell me, how's your wife? [Sir A. enters house.] I shall lose her, here'll be no elopement; no being pur∣sued by her relations—hunted by the Court of Chan∣cery —advertis'd by Government, or what's best of
all, carried to the fleet, or King's Bench, 'midst the shouts of old Maids, and groans of boarding school Misses!—oh!

DIV3.STAGE: Enter SOPHIA from the house, her cloak on.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —So Heav'n be prais'd I've made my escape! James, by bribery and entreaties, unlock'd the door, and now if I knew where to fly for protection—

SP.SPEAKER: Nom—[Having observed her.]
SP.P: Fly! into my arms my angel—I'll put you into that chaise in a moment, out of town in an instant, at Gretna Green in a second, and in all the newspapers and print shops before to-morrow morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —Upon my word Sir, I'm very much obliged to you; [curtseying,] pray may I ask who you are?

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Who I am! why if you don't know me, you know nothing—I'm Nominal.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —Nominal; is it possible! what, the Gentle∣man who so generously releas'd me from the Colonel, and has since made so much noise and confusion?

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Yes: I'm the man; I've made a noise: and if you love Notoriety, you must prefer me to all Heroes past, present, or to come; my angel!— [taking her hand.] where, and how shall I conduct you?—as far as near as you please; [aside] I shall get as much fame by two miles, as two hundred, for though I mean to be honour∣able, I know the world is too scandalous to think me so.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —Ah! I wish I could depend upon you; you see I've no resource, I must either return to the tyranny of my Guardian, or trust to your honour and generosity.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Trust! look'ye, my charming girl;—I've had an intrigue without an intimacy—a duel without enmity—and I meant to have had an elopement with∣out matrimony; but by Heaven! there's something in your person and manner so won upon me, that let me have the fame of carrying you off, and hereafter you shall dispose of me as you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —I believe you: and if you will conduct me to a relation's house, a few miles from town—

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Come along Sophia—faith!—I've been so long looking for a creature as eccentric as myself, that now I've found one, I'll not easily part with it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A—[Within.]
SP.P: Where are you all? James!

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —My Guardian's voice—make haste, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Farewell, old misery! and once more for No∣toriety.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —There they go!—that devil of a fellow has carried her off!—I'll pursue them—I'll—

SP.SPEAKER: Col—[As speaking to Nominal.]
SP.P: Huzza!—that's right—away with her!—look old boy!—look there, first he intrigues with your wife, and then he elopes with your Ward! is'nt he a fine fellow? is'nt he like me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Yes: he's as like you as one madman is another —but I'll overtake him! I'll make him studious again, or beat him as soundly as he beat you! oh! I'll be re∣veng'd!

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —I knew I should bring him up to some purpose; instead of practising law, he'll promote it now; and then for a general election—Oh! what a scene will he make at a general election!

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —And has you honour found him out at last? by my soul I always said he was as full of mischief as yourself, ma foi!

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Yes: that he is!—he's me in every thing— and here thou dear Tutor—here's something for the pains you have taken in finishing his education

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —Bien oblige your honour—I never wanted the dear cratures more in my life, for there's a fine young jontleman just thrown into prison, who has'nt a sous to save him from starvation—So d'ye see, as he once did me a bit of a service, I'll do him another; and then there'll be no mauvaise honte betwixt us you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —What is his name O'Whack?

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —Monsieur Clairville!—poor lad! I believe he was just going to the Eastern Indies, to bring home a large fortune in his pocket, and a little hole in his liver.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Clairville in prison!

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —C'est vrais Jewel—his brother who is a Lord and not a Gentleman d'ye see, had him tap'd on the shoulder and thrown into goal for a thousand Louis d'ors.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —I know his brother's treachery well, and now rejoice that Nominal befriended Clairville instead of in∣juring him—but go to him O'Whack, tell him I'll see Lord Jargon and do all in my power to assist him—go, and comfort him.

SP.SPEAKER: O'W
SP.P: —I'll go directly, and ten thousand blessings on your honour into the bargain—bon jours, oh! by the eternal pow'rs! I wish we had his Lordship in Ireland, I'd lay my best Chapeau to a Thirteener, he'd never make a speech about the good of his country again.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Poor Clairville! I'll enquire into the matter in∣stantly, and then to hear what Nominal has done with Sophia—oh! the dear fellow! now,

Q.L: The breed will be preserv'd from Sire to Sire,
And future Hubbubs, keep the world on fire!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE—An Apartment with glass doors.
DIV3.STAGE: HONORIA enters from doors and seeing Lady ACID entering shuts them in great agitation.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —Heav'ns! Lady Acid!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —What's the matter with you now?—what makes you look so pale?

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —Nothing Ma'am!—nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —I come to tell you, that, that wretch Clairville is in prison, and will remain there for ever unless you have discretion enough to accept Lord Jar∣gon's offers—then he'll be releas'd: nay, none of your airs, his Lordship is honourable, he means marri∣age.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —Marriage!—can his Lordship have the con∣descension?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Yes, and see where he comes to make his own proposals.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —I've been telling Honoria, my Lord, that you'll have the humanity to release your profligate bro∣ther from prison, if she will consent to share your title and fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —And I am to be the happy man?

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —Never my Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —How!—never!

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —No—let me be the simple Honoria, and en∣joy self-approbation, rather than be the wife of your Lordship and lose the congratulations of my own heart!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Hear me Honoria, think of the title, the fashion—

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —Fashion!—contemptible!—I'm weary of the very word; what has it ever done that there should be such magic in it's found! Has it reliev'd poverty, lessen'd oppression, or wip'd away the tear of suffering virtue; name it not then, nor name his Lordship as a husband, I shall treat both with equal disdain.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —More sentiments, and where they come from, Heaven only knows.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Mighty fine Madam, but since you're so arrogant, the Colonel shall be told of your behaviour, he shall hear of your mean, mercenary disposition; what! though you pretend to despise his Lordship; you can receive jewels from him.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —Jewels!—Heav'ns; was I not compell'd Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —No matter—the proof is against you— they are in your possession, and when your Uncle hears of it, I'm sure he won't refuse his Lordship's offers.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Won't he? but he will though, though I love a lad of spirit, I detest premeditated villainy as much as any man; your Brother Clairville is in prison my Lord and I'm told by your means.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —Yes Sir, 'tis so, by his, his Brother's means.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Peace! and let me speak: Colonel, not∣withstanding your prejudices against me and Lord Jargon, I know when you hear the conduct of this mean, avari∣cious girl, you'll confess that his Lordship has a greater claim to her, than any other man—you'll allow, fine diamonds are rare things.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Yes: next to modesty and good sense, the rarest things now-a-days to be met with.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Then Sir, with shame I mention it; she has receiv'd a neck-lace, from his Lordship worth two thousand pounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —How! is this true my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —I can't answer you—but I won't deny it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —She will tell you, that I compell'd her to accept the neck-lace, but even if that were the case, she might have return'd it to his Lordship long e'er this time,

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —'Tis too plain; I see it by her blushes—base, sordid girl, where are the diamonds? produce and give them back to his Lordship, or I swear—go fetch them instantly—What! do you hesitate?

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —I have it not by me sir—I—

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —What have you done with it then?

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —To confess the truth Sir—I have sold it.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. and Lady A
SP.P: —Sold it!

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —Yes Sir—to redeem a picture, to—

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —A picture! give two thousand pounds for a picture; lets see that.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —See, she hesitates again; oh, it's all an im∣position, and my lord has been defrauded out of his diamonds.

SP.SPEAKER: Hon
SP.P: —Wait but a moment, and I'll shew you how he has been defrauded, [Opens glass doors, and lends out Clairville.] Here is the jewel the neck-lace has redeemed —here is a treasure worth ten times its value; and here is the man I shall adore as long as I live.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Clairville!

SP.SPEAKER: Clair
SP.P: —Yes! that Clairville who must have sunk a victim to yours [to Lady.] and his Lordship's artifices, had not this lovely angel stretch'd out her hand and sav'd me from destruction.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Well: this is the prettiest picture I ever saw, look my Lord, look Lady Acid.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —I never was better pleas'd in my life, ha! ha! damnation!

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Nay: pray look—youll not see such a picture again, and what's bettr you'll never see your diamonds again—Clairville, I give you joy, and almost wish you Honoria's husband, but I've lef all that to my Ward, the dear boy has the sole disposal of her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A
SP.P: —Has he? then I op he'll marry her him∣self—any thing, rather than she should be thrown away on a pitiful younger brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Here we are, the two wonders of the age— the elopement's all over the town already: and now what do you think is the next piece of mischief we've resolv'd on?

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —What?

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Marriage!

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P:
—Ay: so it is—I never thought of it. We've hurried ourselves into it, and what's more, we've hur∣ried Sir Andrew into it; and now if you'll consent—
but dispatch, intreat you be quick, for the Lady's all on fire! and I'm—ugh.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Why Sophia, is this true?

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —Even so Colonel, you were so inconstant, that I was obliged to accept another gay deceiver.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —Well, well, take her with all my heart; so the glorious breed is preserv'd. I don't care who it is by, but you rogue, you must give up singularity now.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Must I? no, I'll be more singular than ever, I'll be so true, so faithful, and so constant a husband, that the whole fashionable world shall laugh at me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady A—[Aside to Lord.]
SP.P: This is fortunate, now he's married himself, perhaps he may give you Honoria— ask him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —I will, [aside.] Nominal a word—

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —What? my little antagonist!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —I know you are as much above receiving a bribe, as I am of offering one, but if you'll make Honoria mine, I'll give you half her fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —If you'd give me your own into the bargain, I would not dispose of her so dishonourably; no, no, your brother is my friend, and if I have any interest in Honoria, I hope she may be his for ever; and now all I recommend to you, and my old acquaintance here, [Lady Acid] is to leave the world, and take the wax figure along with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —That's right my boy, all shall be join'd to night hands, hearts and estates; I'll give Clairville property, and if his Lordship has any more presents, another dia∣mond neck-lace, why he may settle it on the first child.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —Won't you follow her my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Jar
SP.P: —I follow her! not for a thousand worlds.

SP.SPEAKER: Soph
SP.P: —Sir Andrew, I hope you have forgiven me every thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P:
—Yes, yes, you and your kindred genius have tormented me so much, that I could'nt be better reveng'd
than by marrying you together. I've lost a wife, and the student has lound one, that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: Col
SP.P: —"Which has the better bargain?" od's life! old boy, an't you delighted to see us all so merry?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir A
SP.P: —Faith! I think I am, but don't be too hard upon me, don't be too merry lest the devil that's within me, should tempt me to make long faces again.

SP.SPEAKER: Nom
SP.P: —If he does, it must be at another time, and in another place.

Q.L: Good humour reigns so absolutely here,
That when there's cause for cenfure—none we fear;
So great their candour—they so seldom blame—
That even Nominal may get a name,
